Award.AwardTitle: Organic Acids, Catalysts, and Mass Spectrometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic and Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Steven R Kass of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Minnesota will explore networks of hydrogen bonds. The goal of this research is to learn about the consequences of multiple hydrogen bonds and develop new environmentally friendly acids, bases, catalysts, and sensors, as well as a better understanding of how enzymes work. This project lies at the interface of organic, physical, analytical, and biochemistry, and as such it is well suited for educating and training students from high school to graduate and postgraduate studies. Large numbers of students are exposed to this research in organic chemistry classes and the department's NSF-REU, Lando (domestic and international) and Khorana/Bose (international) summer research programs.

Bio-inspired acids, bases, hydrogen bond catalysts, and anion molecular receptors which make use of multiple intramolecular hydrogen bonds will be prepared. Their properties (e.g., pKa's) and reactivities will be explored, and new insights into hydrogen bond networks will be obtained. By carrying out a variety of physical measurements including those in the gas phase, and examining chiral reagents, the effect of different types of hydrogen bonds will be determined. This should facilitate the design and development of useful reagents and sensors, as well as providing insights into naturally occurring biological processes such as enzyme-catalyzed transformations, protein folding, and ion transport.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new strategy for improving the performance of practical and environmentally friendly catalysts was investigated and initial results were reported in the scientific literature. Hydrogen bond and Bronsted acid organocatalysts with enhanced abilities were developed. It was found that the incorporation of positively charged centers into hydrogen bond donors increases their acidities and catalytic abilities. These encouraging results led us to explore asymmetric catalysts which can produce chiral products selectively. That is, molecules with the property of handedness were prepared and their ability to generate left or right handed products (i.e., one mirror image over another) were explored since naturally occurring compounds and most drugs have this property. Our initial results in this area are promising and one manuscript has been submitted and another will follow shortly.

Hydrogen bond donors also can bind negative ions (anions) selectively. This form of molecular recognition is important for environmental, industrial, medical, and chemical reasons. One of our catalysts was found to bind phosphate strongly enough that it can be used to extract this ion out of water. Given that one third of the large lakes in the United States are contaminated with phosphate and that it is an agricultural and industrial pollutant, as well as a species related to a number of human diseases, the development of such compounds has many potential practical applications. One example is sensors for the detection of phosphate, an NSF priority area. To address this, ion selective electrodes were prepared and the acidities of the receptors were measured. Encouraging results were obtained.

The sponsored research provided an invaluable platform for training large numbers of young scientists ranging from a high school student to college undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral associates. Students that worked in the Kass laboratory had an opportunity to synthesize, purify and characterize organic compounds, carry out computations at the Minnesota Supercomputer Institute for Advanced Computational Research, analyze data, problem solve and work with modern chemical instrumentation. Opportunities to work on oral and written presentations were also provided.


Last Modified: 10/11/2017
Modified by: Steven R Kass
